title-group.article-title: A Strategic Rationale for the Use of Sell–On Fees in European Sports

fn.p: Oliver Gürtler has received his PhD from University of Bonn (2006) and is currently an economics professor at University of Cologne. His fields of research include personnel economics, organizational economics, sports economics and contest theory.

abstract.p: In European team sports, contracts that govern the transfer of a player from one club to another often contain a clause specifying a sell-on fee. Such clause ensures that the selling club profits from a future transfer of the player. This article gives possible explanations for the use of sell-on fees. Besides rather obvious explanations based on risk considerations and wealth constraints, the article shows that a sell-on fee could be used for strategic reasons. In particular, the clubs may agree on a sell-on fee since it affects the behavior of the buying club in future transfer negotiations in a favorable way.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In European team sports, a player that is under contract with a club can switch to another club only if the player’s club agrees to terminate his contract. Typically, a club does so only in exchange for a financial compensation by the other club. The main part of such compensation is paid unconditionally and known as the “transfer fee.” The size of such fees can be substantial, with €93 million being the world record when Cristiano Ronaldo left Manchester United to join Real Madrid in 2009.1

In general, however, the financial compensation does not only consist of an unconditional fee but of other elements as well. In particular, the clubs often agree on a so-called sell-on fee that allows the selling club to profit from any future transfer of the player. For example, when Jérôme Boateng was transferred from Hamburger SV to Manchester City in summer 2010, Boateng’s former club Hertha Berlin received 20% of the €12.5 million paid by Manchester to Hamburg.2

A sell-on fee might be used for different reasons. First, risk considerations may play a role. Such fee increases the selling club’s income in case of a future transfer, while it probably leads to a lower unconditional fee and, hence, a lower present income. Of course, things are the other way round for the buying club. More generally, a sell-on fee affects the income stream of the two clubs involved in the transfer, which may be beneficial if the clubs (or the club owners/managers) are risk-averse. Second, a sell-on fee may be useful if the buying club is wealth-constrained and, thus, not able to pay an unconditional fee high enough to convince the other club to sell the player. Here, the prospect of receiving additional income in the future may be necessary to make the deal attractive for the selling club. Third, there may be (less obvious) strategic reasons that may lead the clubs to agree on a sell-on fee. More concretely, a sell-on fee may improve the buying club’s position in future transfer negotiations. A simple example may illustrate this effect. Suppose that a player has been transferred from a club A to a club B and that B values the player at €7 million. Suppose also that a third Club C wants to hire the player away. If no sell-on fee has been installed, C has to offer at least €7 million to make the deal attractive for B. If, instead, there is a sell-on fee of, for example, €2 million, C has to offer at least €9 million because B has to give part of the transfer fee to A. In sum, a sell-on fee could be used by A and B to demand a higher payment from C in future negotiations. This, however, comes at the risk that C may find it no longer worthwhile to pursue the transfer.
The current article focuses on the strategic effects of a sell-on fee. It analyzes the trade-off just described and derives the determinants of an optimally chosen sell-on fee.

The article is related to two strands of economic literature. First, there is a literature dealing with transfer agreements in European sports. In main parts, this literature highlights the effects of different institutional arrangements on the outcome of transfer negotiations.3 Most important in this respect is the analysis of the potential effects of the so-called Bosman ruling, a decision of the European Court of Justice, which allows players in the European Union to move freely to another club at the end of their term of contract with their present club. The current article differs from this literature in that it focuses more closely on the optimal design of transfer contracts. Second, I have argued before that a sell-on fee is useful to affect the buying club’s position in future transfer negotiations. Therefore, the article is also related to the literature that analyzes how a bargaining process could be influenced in one’s favor. For example, this could be achieved by means of strategic delegation (Cai and Cont, 2004; Fingleton and Raith, 2005) or, in the context of a supplier—buyer relationship, by vertical integration (Grossman and Hart, 1986; Hart and Moore, 1990).

The article is organized as follows: The next section contains the model description, while the model solution is presented in the section on Model Solution. The last section discusses implications of the model and avenues for future research.

sec.title: Model Description
sec.p:
We consider a model with two periods, t = 1, 2. The economic environment in each of the periods is as follows:
t = 1: There is a player who is currently employed at a club, A. The value of the player to this club is a > 0 in every period. There is a second club, B, which values the player at b > a in every period and which wants to sign the player. Before the period starts, the two clubs bargain over a transfer of the player to club B. We keep the bargaining process simple and assume that A (B) can make a take-it-or-leave-it offer to B (A) with probability r ∈ (0,1) (1 – r).4 The payoffs to the two clubs depend on whether the player is transferred and, if this is the case, on the transfer payments made by club B.
t = 2: There is a third club C that takes notice of the player. The value of the player to this club in t = 2 is denoted c. While all clubs know c in t = 2, this parameter is unknown in t = 1. sec.title: The Second Period
sec.p:
The model is solved by backward induction. Therefore, we start with the negotiation in the second period. If the player is still with club A in t = 2, the clubs will always agree on a transfer to club C. This is because the clubs know that the player is more valuable to C so that they can always find a transfer fee that makes both of them (weakly) better off. The exact size of this fee depends on who is allowed to make the take-it-or-leave-it offer. If club A makes the offer, it demands the highest fee that C is willing to pay. sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
The previous analysis has shown that the high sell-on fee
f 2

f C

c h
− b
should be chosen if θ and cl are rather low or ch is high. From these findings, a testable implication can be derived. For a young and unknown player, it is often difficult to predict his exact development and what the future value of this player to club C will be. This means that for a young player, the difference ch − cl should be relatively high. Similarly, θ should not be too low. According to the model, we should then expect the clubs to agree on a high sell-on fee. It would be very interesting to test this model implication with real-world data. One problem with this kind of research is that clubs rarely reveal the exact contents of transfer agreements so that it is hard to come up with the necessary data. Anecdotal evidence, however, suggests that the implication could be true. As already mentioned in the introduction, a sell-on fee was specified in the contract governing the transfer of then 18-year-old Jérôme Boateng from Berlin to Hamburg. Other examples for the use of sell-on fees in contracts governing the transfers of relatively young players (according to different newspaper reports) include Gareth Bale (at the age of 18, from Southampton to Tottenham), Lukas Podolski (21, Cologne → Munich), Rafael van der Vaart (22, Amsterdam → Hamburg), Joleon Lescott (23, Wolverhampton → Everton), or Aly Cissokho (21, Porto → Lyon).

A second problem with the proposed kind of research is that an explanation for sell-on fees based on risk aversion may lead to similar conclusions. To understand this, suppose that the owner/manager of club B is risk averse and that there is no sell-on fee. Then B has a high income if, in the second-period transfer negotiations, it can make a take-it-or-leave-it offer to C while it has a lower income if C makes the offer. Now oppose this to a situation where a sell-on fee has been specified by A and B in Period 1 and, to compensate for this, the unconditional transfer fee paid by B to A has been reduced. If the size of the sell-on fee were increasing in the transfer fee paid by C in Period 2, the sell-on fee would be relatively higher in the case where B is allowed to make the offer to C. Accordingly, it would help to smooth B’s income stream, which may be beneficial if risk considerations play a role. Moreover, the described benefits should be particularly high for players with high ch − cl , as for those players the expected differences in club B’s income are rather high.

A possible way to discriminate between the two explanations is by also considering the parameter s that specifies the relative bargaining power of the clubs. The model predicts the high sell-on fee to be optimal if s is rather low, that is, if club C is known to be a good bargainer (e.g., because C has an experienced manager). With a low value for s, however, the income of B does not vary a lot since C offers a fixed amount of money with high probability. This means that a sell-on fee might not be observed if s is low and risk aversion is the driving force behind the use of sell-on fees.

The model implication just described can be used to derive a second model implication concerning the design of player contracts. As explained before, young players should be rather risky since not much is known yet about their abilities. As argued, for example, on page 4 of Lazear and Gibbs (2008), firms may want to hire risky workers. The argument is that firms can earn profits from the workers if they turn out to be good, while they can fire them otherwise. In football, player performances are highly visible. Hence, a club can earn high profits from a player only if the player is under contract and not allowed to move to another club without his club’s approval. Accordingly, clubs may want to offer contracts of long duration. However, then they are not able to fire the players in case they perform badly. There is a way out of this dilemma: a club hiring a young and risky player could offer the player a contract of rather short duration, but specify an option which allows the club to extend the contract.6 Combining the thoughts of this paragraph and the preceding ones, we may thus conclude that sell-on fees in transfer contracts and contract-extension options in player contracts should be used at the same time.

In the model, we have assumed that renegotiation of the original contract by A and B is not possible. It is easy to show that the model results continue to hold (qualitatively) if renegotiation is possible but not completely costless. To see this, reconsider the example from the introduction. There we argued that C has to offer €9 million to B if there is a sell-on fee of €2 million and B values the player at €7 million. Now let renegotiation of the contract by A and B be feasible and suppose that C makes a take-it-or-leave-it offer to B of €7 million only. If A and B do not renegotiate the contract and, hence, B declines the offer, A gets a second-period profit of zero, while B gets €7 million (B’s value for the player). Now let renegotiation take place. In order to make the transfer feasible, the sell-on fee has to be deleted from the contract. Then, A’s payoff is still zero (since A does no longer participate in the future sale of the player), while B still gets €7 million (the transfer fee paid by C). As a consequence, the clubs would be willing to renegotiate the contract only if this were completely costless (or C would offer more than €7 million to B in which case the sell-on fee would regain its strategic value). Note in this respect that it is reasonable to assume that renegotiation is not costless since the clubs have to spend time and to pay lawyers’ fees in the renegotiation process.

An interesting array for future research would be to analyze further clauses used in transfer contracts. In addition to clauses specifying sell-on fees, transfer contracts sometimes contain clauses depending on the player’s success at the buying club or clauses, depending on the buying club’s success following the transfer. Of course, it is important to understand why these alternative clauses are used in transfer contracts.

Finally, it should be noted that sell-on fees play a role in other industries as well, for example, in arts. Here, many countries give artists (or their successors) the so-called resale royalty rights. According to these rights, artists receive a percentage of the value of sales in transactions of their artworks subsequent to the first transfer of ownership. Hence, the importance of the analysis of sell-on fees is not restricted to the sports industry.
